metadata.case_name: Collector of Bombay v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay

facts.text: In 1865, Government of Bombay decided to construct Eastern Boulevard and called upon Corporation of Justices of the Peace for the City of Bombay to remove existing fish and vegetable markets from the site.
Municipal Commissioner Arthur Crawford applied for site set aside for exhibition buildings on Esplanades to construct new markets.
On December 5, 1865, Architectural Improvement Committee informed Government no objection to site measuring about 7 acres being rented to Municipal Commissioner at one pie per square yard.

On December 19, 1865, Government passed resolution approving site grant without rent as markets for benefit of whole community; possession given but no formal grant executed as per Statute 22-23 Vic. C. 41.
Municipal Commissioner filled up and levelled site at Corporation expense; plans approved, market buildings erected at considerable expense.
Respondent Corporation incorporated in 1888 as successor; continued possession without paying rent per 1865 Resolution.
Corporation and predecessor spent considerable sums, total Rs. 17,65,980-12-1 up to March 31, 1940, in filling, levelling, erecting and maintaining market; no land revenue or rent paid since grant.
In 1911, portion of market site acquired for Palton Road widening; Collector/Superintendent City Survey stated Government had no claim; Corporation received full compensation.
On March 18, 1938, appellant Collector informed Municipal Commissioner of proposal to assess Crawford Market land under s.8 Bombay City Land Revenue Act II of 1876.
Municipal Commissioner replied site given as gift, no assessment; Collector insisted right to assess.
Mayor of Bombay wrote March 23, 1939, asserting permanent rent-free grant, 'rent' meaning land revenue; possession over 70 years without interruption.
Government replied January 1, 1940, prerogative right not lost by non-user; conditions changed, levy cannot be foregone.
Collector assessed land January 31, 1940: Rs.7,500 first 10 years, Rs.15,000 next 10, Rs.30,000 remaining 30, from April 1, 1940.
Suit filed by respondents in Revenue Judge Court for declaration of right to hold land forever without assessment, assessment ultra vires.
Revenue Judge dismissed suit October 27, 1942 with costs.
High Court (Sen and Dixit JJ.) allowed appeal February 21, 1947, reversed Revenue Judge, declared rights, costs.
No compliance with formalities of Statute 22-23 Vic. C. 41; 1865 Resolution invalid as grant or contract.
Government Resolution intended no rent charge; both parties acted on it; possession over 70 years.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondent Corporation established a right in limitation of Government's right to assess under s.8 Bombay City Land Revenue Act II of 1876, in consequence of specific limit to assessment (nil) established and preserved.
Whether equity per Ramsden v. Dyson applies to limit Government's prerogative right to assess despite invalid grant.
Whether adverse possession perfected title to hold land free of rent/assessment for market purpose.
Distinction between rent and land revenue; whether prerogative right separate.

petitioner_arguments.text: 1865 Resolution invalid as grant or contract due to non-compliance with Statute 22-23 Vic. C. 41; no legal title or enforceable contract.
Crown's prerogative right to levy assessment not lost by non-user; ordinary presumption of grant does not apply.
No equity per Ramsden v. Dyson; part performance doctrine does not override statutory formalities per Privy Council in Ariff v. Jadunath.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ramsden v. Dyson; Ariff v. Jadunath; Maddison v. Alderson

petitioner_arguments.text: Adverse possession perfects title to land but not exemption from prerogative assessment right, which is collateral.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Limitation Act s.28; Goswamini Shri Kamalavahooji v. Collector of Bombay

petitioner_arguments.text: Rent and land revenue distinct; Government not precluded from assessing.

respondent_arguments.text: Equity per Ramsden v. Dyson: Government encouraged expectation of rent-free possession; Corporation expended money on faith thereof; equity limits assessment right.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ramsden v. Dyson; Municipal Corporation v. Secretary of State

respondent_arguments.text: Site given as permanent grant free from rent/assessment ('rent' includes land revenue); possession over 70 years without objection.
S.8 applies even to nil specific limit per Kamalavahooji Maharaj v. Collector of Bombay.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay City Land Revenue Act s.8

court_reasoning.text: 1865 Resolution invalid grant/contract due to statutory non-compliance; no legal title passed.
Possession under invalid grant prima facie adverse; continued openly for over 70 years; perfected limited title to hold in perpetuity free of rent for market purpose per Resolution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Immunity from rent integral to title acquired; constitutes specific limit (nil) under s.8.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide equity in Ramsden v. Dyson; dispose on adverse possession ground.
Ramsden v. Dyson based on part performance/estoppel; cannot override statutory formalities per Privy Council; no estoppel by representation or acquiescence.
Adverse possession of land extinguishes Government property right but prerogative assessment separate/collateral; cannot acquire exemption thereby.
'Rent' in Resolution means assessment/land revenue; representation acted upon; equity/estoppel prevents Government going back.
Rent/revenue not distinct here; not raised below.

holdings.text: Respondent acquired by adverse possession right to hold land in perpetuity free of rent/assessment for market purpose; specific limit nil under s.8.

precedents_cited.relevance: Equity where landlord encourages expectation of permanent interest, tenant expends money.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay v. The Secretary of State
precedents_cited.relevance: Applied Ramsden equity despite invalid disposition; may need reconsideration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dadoba Janardhan v. The Collector of Bombay
Jethabhoy Ruttonsey v. The Collector of Bombay
Kamalavahooji Maharaj v. The Collector of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: S.8 applies to nil limit/total exemption.
Part performance cannot override statutory formalities like TP Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Goswamini Shri Kamalavahooji v. Collector of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: No presumption of lost grant for revenue exemption; words of s.8 cover exemption.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mian Pir Bux v. Sardar Mahomed
precedents_cited.relevance: Equitable doctrines not defence to ejectment.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay City Land Revenue Act, 1876
statutes_cited.relevance: Collector to levy assessment; limited if specific limit established/preserved (includes nil).

statutes_cited.name: Statute 22 & 23 Vic. C. 41
statutes_cited.relevance: Formalities for Crown disposition of property.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Extinguishment of right by adverse possession.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed with costs; High Court decision upheld declaring respondent's right to hold land free from assessment under s.8 as specific limit (nil) established by adverse possession under invalid 1865 grant.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration of right in limitation of Government's assessment right; assessment set aside.
outcome.costs: Costs in favour of respondents in this Court and below.

key_quotes.text: "Government do not consider any rent should be charged to the Municipality as the markets will be, like other public buildings, for the benefit of the whole community."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the right to levy the assessment is the prerogative of the Crown and a mere non-user of this prerogative cannot destroy it."
key_quotes.speaker: appellant

key_quotes.text: "Such possession not being referable to any legal title it was prima facie adverse to the legal title of the Government... has acquired the limited title... right to hold the land in perpetuity free from rent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Das J. reasoning on adverse possession (majority).

key_quotes.text: "exemption from land revenue does not form part and parcel of the title to land but is collateral to it."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Courts must do justice by the promotion of honesty and good faith... a different conclusion would be opposed to what is reasonable, to what is probable, and to what is fair."
key_quotes.speaker: court
